text: Hi. Beginner here. Is there a one-liner to convert in place a DataFrame column that has yyyymmdd (e.g. 19991231) as Int64 to Date type? Thank you.

elements.text: Hi. Beginner here. Is there a one-liner to convert in place a DataFrame column that has yyyymmdd (e.g. 19991231) as Int64 to Date type? Thank you.

text: check out the Dates package. You need to specify the correct DateFormat though

elements.text: check out the Dates package. You need to specify the correct DateFormat though

text: I think you need a string, i.e. `Date(string(19991231), dateformat"yyyymmdd")`

elements.text: I think you need a string, i.e.

text: Thank you, both. I was wondering whether there is more direct way than converting the DataFrame column from int to string to Date.

elements.text: Thank you, both. I was wondering whether there is more direct way than converting the DataFrame column from int to string to Date.

text: Why is it an integer to begin with?

elements.text: Why is it an integer to begin with?

text: It's important to note that there is nothing special about a DataFrames column. It's just a normal julia vector, so there are unlikely to be special packages for that kind of thing (this is a good, essential feature of the language)

elements.text: It's important to note that there is nothing special about a DataFrames column. It's just a normal julia vector, so there are unlikely to be special packages for that kind of thing (this is a good, essential feature of the language)

text: Thanks. <@U7PGB5DU3> I used CSV.jl to read the data into a DataFrame. I noticed that the variable types can be explicitly specified which gets around the conversion (<https://csv.juliadata.org/stable/#Key-Functions>)

elements.text: I used CSV.jl to read the data into a DataFrame. I noticed that the variable types can be explicitly specified which gets around the conversion (

text: also, CSV will automatically convert date strings to dates, even without specifying it explicitly. I think.

elements.text: also, CSV will automatically convert date strings to dates, even without specifying it explicitly. I think.

text: I guess that since the dates were given as integers, i.e. 19991231 (instead of as a string), they were recognized as integers and thus the type had to be specified.

elements.text: I guess that since the dates were given as integers, i.e. 19991231 (instead of as a string), they were recognized as integers and thus the type had to be specified.

text: oh right. but I'm glad this got solved so easily, otherwise, it sounds like a nice little rabbit hole: how to convert an int to year, month, day integers (and feed that into Date)...
